timeline.bodyText: Why is this call not deferred ?
timeline.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: Same as above. We only need to defer a call when certain variables or conditions must be met. For example, 2 lines down - the authenticateWithConfidentialClient() should happen only if there's a cache miss. But for this line, we have all the variables needed initialized, and reading from the cache should always happen without conditions.
replies.author: jianghaolu

timeline.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: Fixed.

timeline.bodyText: Why are we doing Exceptions.propagate and not directly converting to Runtime Exception ?
timeline.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: @alzimmermsft suggested this usage pattern to me.
replies.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText: Actually I know a reason - if e is already a subclass of RuntimeException, wrapping it in another RuntimeException is bad. Exceptions.propagate(e) will check if e is a RuntimeException first and only wrap if not.
replies.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText:
Okay,
But we already know, MalformedURLException is not a RuntimeException here.
So, that check is redundant.
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: That's correct. But at this point it's really a personal preference thing. I changed it to new RuntimeException() for the if check it saves. But one could argue in the future if more exceptions are thrown or this code path is refactored to merge with other paths that could throw RuntimeExceptions this could potentially be a point of failure. The point is, it's not critical.
replies.author: jianghaolu

timeline.bodyText: Do we expect MSAL to return an expired token ?
timeline.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: No. But a non-expired IAuthenticationResult could be an expired AccessToken because of the offset. In my token refresh offset re-work, this line will be changed to .filter(t -> OffsetDateTime.now().isBefore(t.getExpiresAt().minus(identityClientOptions.getTokenRefreshOffset()))); But for now this may look a little confusing.
replies.author: jianghaolu

timeline.bodyText: Is Mono.defer() necessary? You can simply do switchIfEmpty(identityClient.authenticateWithConfidentialClient(request)) since this gets triggered only if the cache returns empty result and doesn't have to be deferred.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: @alzimmermsft asked the same question. if we do switchIfEmpty(identityClient.authenticateWithConfidentialClient(request)) the method call identityClient.authenticateWithConfidentialClient(request) will be evaluated first but we do not want that.

timeline.bodyText: Should this throw an exception if httpClient is null and proxy options are set?
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: No - it's a valid scenario which is handled in line 177: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/pull/11355/files/1c100d5ba097af9d5ba670b34d010f25d5606681#diff-56093106beda983b28894478869221c6R177. Basically, the only time we don't want to initialize the httpPipelineAdapter is when a proxy option is provided - in which case we pass the proxy option directly to MSAL for backward compatibility. New users should set the proxy options on the httpClient.
replies.author: jianghaolu
